children.value: This notebook contains some interactive graphical examples and a simple sample numerical constrained optimization.  This notebook uses widgets from the
library which will not be rendered in a static view.
The consumer chooses a consumption bundle

max⁡x0,x1U(x0,x1)\max_{x_0,x_1} U(x_0,x_1)x0​,x1​max​U(x0​,x1​)
p⋅x0+x1≤Ip \cdot x_0 + x_1 \leq Ip⋅x0​+x1​≤I
p=p0p1p=\frac{p_{0}}{p_{1}}p=p1​p0​​

children.value: is the relative price of good 0 measured in terms of units of good 1.
If we choose a Cobb-Douglas utility function of the form

children.html: U(x0,x1)=α⋅log(x0)+(1−α)⋅log(x1)U(x_0, x_1) = \alpha \cdot log(x_0) + (1-\alpha) \cdot log(x_1)U(x0​,x1​)=α⋅log(x0​)+(1−α)⋅log(x1​)

children.value: We can solve for the Marshallian demands in a variety of ways. For example by using the binding budget constraint to substitute for

max⁡x0α⋅log(x0)+(1−α)⋅log(I−p⋅x0)\max_{x_0} \alpha \cdot log(x_0) + (1-\alpha) \cdot log(I - p \cdot x_0)x0​max​α⋅log(x0​)+(1−α)⋅log(I−p⋅x0​)

children.value: The first-order necessary condition (FOC) for an interior optimum,

children.html: αx0=p⋅1−αI−p⋅x0\frac{\alpha}{x_0} = p \cdot \frac{1-\alpha}{I-p \cdot x_0}x0​α​=p⋅I−p⋅x0​1−α​

children.value: , can be solved to give us the Marshallian demand function for

x1(p,I)x_1(p,I)x1​(p,I)
x0∗=α⋅Ipx1∗=(1−α)⋅I\begin{aligned} x_0^* &= \alpha \cdot \frac{I}{p} \\ x_1^* &= (1-\alpha) \cdot I \end{aligned}x0∗​x1∗​​=α⋅pI​=(1−α)⋅I​

children.value: If we substitute in prices, income and the share parameter we find the vector of Marshallian demands

children.html: [x0∗,x1∗][x_0^*, x_1^*][x0∗​,x1∗​]

children.value: from which we can also find the indirect utility funtion

children.html: V(p,I)=U(x0∗,x1∗)V(p,I) =U(x_0^*, x_1^*)V(p,I)=U(x0∗​,x1∗​)

children.value: We’ve written some python functions for the graphs and numerical solutions below, most of which are placed in the

import sys
from IPython.display import display, Latex
sys.path.insert(0,'..')  
from cd import *    # import cobb douglas python library of functions
In the next cell control plot parameters with sliders (will only display if running with live kernel)
Move the slider to move the consumption point along the budget line. Keep adjusting until we reach the highest indifference curve at a tangency point.
In the diagram below we’ve guessed that the optimum is the point along the budget constraint

children.html: (x0,x1)=(20,80)(x_0, x_1)=(20, 80)(x0​,x1​)=(20,80)

children.value: but when we check this, we verify that

children.html: MU0p0>MU1p1\frac{MU_0}{p_0} > \frac{MU_1}{p_1}p0​MU0​​>p1​MU1​​

children.value: Since the marginal utility per dollar spent on good 0 is larger than the marginal utility per dollar spent on good 1, utility can be increased by moving some spending from good 0 to good 1.
In the next interactive diagram, we can move the sliders (this will only change the display if running this notebook with live kernel) to find the optimum.

The problem we have been solving can be easily solved analytically (i.e. we can derive formulas for Marshallian demands) but it’s useful to also see how this type of constrained optimization problem can be solved numerically using the
